TextBody:
Hello Mark,

Thank you for contacting Netwrix Technical Support. 

To help us streamline the troubleshooting process and resolve your issue more efficiently, please provide the following information:  

What is the impact of the issue on your business? 
Who is affected by this issue? 
What steps to troubleshoot the issue have already been taken? 
What are you trying to do or accomplish? 
Is this a new configuration, data collection or report? 
If no, has anything changed in your environment since the last time it worked? 
When did this issue start?  
What are the steps to reproduce? 
What software is currently installed - run this command from an admin Powershell prompt:
Get-CimInstance -Class Win32_Product |Where-Object {($_.Name -Like "Stealth*" -or $_.Name -like "Netwrix*" -or $_.Name -like "Postg*" -or ` $_.Name -like "Python*")} -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue

Please perform the follow steps and upload the resulting Artifacts:

Enable Debug Logging
From the NEA Console > Settings > Application
Set Log Level to Debug
Rerun jobs that are failing to collect logs in full detail. Return Log level to warning afterwards.


Please provide logs from the following locations: 
Enterprise Auditor Console: %SAInstallDir%SADatabaseLogsApplication 
Access Information Center (11.6): C:Program FilesSTEALTHbitsAccess Information Center 
Access Information (11.5): C:inetpubwwwrootStealthAUDIT Compliance 

Export of Job(s) – note jobs may be nested under multiple Groups:
Right click on the Job or Job Group experiencing problems and select Export. This creates .zip file containing all logs and configuration settings of your jobs that we can import and review.


From the Job Status Export the Messages Table, CSV is preferred: 
 

Thank you,

Scottie Taylor
Technical Support Engineer
____________________________
Cybersecurity That Works For You

6160 Warren Parkway, Suite 100, Frisco, TX 75034
www.netwrix.com

TextBody:
Hello Mark,

I've already reviewed the logs and the error messages are just a repeat instance of the error messages in the console with no additional information. If there is additional information in the screenshot in the word document than would be more helpful. 

Additionally, the AD Permissions Analyzer Job is dependent on a successful AD Inventory scan. Is the customer experiencing any issues with that scan? I would also verify the configuration of this job by checking the assigned host list which should be set to "One Domain Controller Per Domain" as well as if the credential that's being used is a local admin or domain admin if the target host is a DC. I have provided documentation to verify these below:
 

	Recommended Configurations for AD Permissions Analyzer Solution

Additionally, I would also verify if the permission requirements are met for the account that's being used in the connection profile with the ADPermissions Data Collector. I have provided that documentation below as well. 

ADPermissions Data Collector

Please let me know if they are still having issues after checking these settings and permissions.

Thank you,

Scottie Taylor
Technical Support Engineer
____________________________
Cybersecurity That Works For You

6160 Warren Parkway, Suite 100, Frisco, TX 75034
www.netwrix.com

Hello Mark,

I've already reviewed the logs and the error messages are just a repeat instance of the error messages in the console with no additional information. If there is additional information in the screenshot in the word document than would be more helpful.

Additionally, the AD Permissions Analyzer Job is dependent on a successful AD Inventory scan. Is the customer experiencing any issues with that scan? I would also verify the configuration of this job by checking the assigned host list which should be set to "One Domain Controller Per Domain" as well as if the credential that's being used is a local admin or domain admin if the target host is a DC. I have provided documentation to verify these below:


  *   Recommended Configurations for AD Permissions Analyzer Solution<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Solutions/ActiveDirectoryPermissionsAnalyzer/Recommended.htm>
Additionally, I would also verify if the permission requirements are met for the account that's being used in the connection profile with the ADPermissions Data Collector. I have provided that documentation below as well.

ADPermissions Data Collector<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Admin/DataCollector/ADPermissions/Overview.htm>

Please let me know if they are still having issues after checking these settings and permissions.

Thank you,

+++++
20/03/2025 16:00:02    WARNING    StealthAUDIT    THostConnection.RecordConnectionAttempt    "Connecting to LEWDC001 using pocnetwrix: ACCESS DENIED"            -1    13152    10824

+++++

Then the "Unable to cast object" error occurs:

20/03/2025 16:00:02    ERROR    ADP    TManagedDCExtractItf.PrepareForTask    "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'"    LEWDC001    DCExtract    5812    13152    10824

2) I see the same warning in the attached "AD_USerRights_log.tsv" and then the same error 5 lines later as well.

+++++
20/03/2025 16:41:12    WARNING    StealthAUDIT    THostConnection.RecordConnectionAttempt    "Connecting to LEWDC001 using pocnetwrix: ACCESS DENIED"            -1    13012    12984
20/03/2025 16:41:12    INFO    StealthAUDIT    TConnectionMgr.RecordConnectionResults    "LEWDC001pocnetwrixACCESS DENIED profile: Netwrix Scanning Account"            -1    13012    12984
+++++


Thank you,

Hello Mark,

I've already reviewed the logs and the error messages are just a repeat instance of the error messages in the console with no additional information. If there is additional information in the screenshot in the word document than would be more helpful.

Additionally, the AD Permissions Analyzer Job is dependent on a successful AD Inventory scan. Is the customer experiencing any issues with that scan? I would also verify the configuration of this job by checking the assigned host list which should be set to "One Domain Controller Per Domain" as well as if the credential that's being used is a local admin or domain admin if the target host is a DC. I have provided documentation to verify these below:


  1.  Recommended Configurations for AD Permissions Analyzer Solution<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Solutions/ActiveDirectoryPermissionsAnalyzer/Recommended.htm>
Additionally, I would also verify if the permission requirements are met for the account that's being used in the connection profile with the ADPermissions Data Collector. I have provided that documentation below as well.

ADPermissions Data Collector<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Admin/DataCollector/ADPermissions/Overview.htm>

Please let me know if they are still having issues after checking these settings and permissions.

Thank you,

Scottie Taylor

Hi Mike

Thanks for sharing the information below.

As I am sure you know when it comes to AD Permission Analyzer there is no special access account needed as all AD Permissions have the “Read” for Any Account created within the Active Directory.

Today I used Dupreez’s account to run a scan using the “AD Container Rights” Job just using his own account and again I get Access denied. Please see below and also see attached Log file for the scan.

[cid:image001.png@01DB9DAD.A05F1310]

I then used the same account to perform an AD Inventory, and it worked as expected. See screen shot below and, I have attached the Log file for that scan to the email.

[cid:image002.png@01DB9DAD.A05F1310]


I get we are using different Data Collectors between the 2 jobs, AD Inv is using LDAP and AD Perms is probably using PowerShell but I have not come across the error we are seeing in the AD Perms job before.


I am note sure what else I can do on my side.


Kind Regards

Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #439010 -  - NEA Permission Analyzer Job Errors    [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0N1Fsf:ref ]

TextBody:
Hi Mark,

I'm not sure I understand your statment below "As I am sure you know when it comes to AD Permission Analyzer there is no special access account needed as all AD Permissions have the “Read” for Any Account created within the Active Directory."

Are you under the impressions that the connection profile only needs membership as a Domain User?

By our documentation the AD Permissions Analyzer group requires to account used in the connection profile to have  Domain Administrator privilege.

https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Solutions/ActiveDirectoryPermissionsAnalyzer/Recommended.htm

"Connection Profile

Assign a Connection Profile at the Active Directory Permissions Analyzer > 0. Collection > Settings > Connection node with local Administrator privileges on the target host, or Domain Administrator privileges if the target host is a domain controller."

Have I misunderstood your statement?


Thank you,

Brandon West
Technical Support Manager
Phone: 1-949-407-5125 | Toll-free: 888-638-9749

6160 warren Parkway, Suite 100, Frisco, TX 75034

Hi Mike

 

Thanks for sharing the information below.

 

As I am sure you know when it comes to AD Permission Analyzer there is no special access account needed as all AD Permissions have the “Read” for Any Account created within the Active Directory.

 

Today I used Dupreez’s account to run a scan using the “AD Container Rights” Job just using his own account and again I get Access denied. Please see below and also see attached Log file for the scan.

 



 

I then used the same account to perform an AD Inventory, and it worked as expected. See screen shot below and, I have attached the Log file for that scan to the email.

 



 

 

I get we are using different Data Collectors between the 2 jobs, AD Inv is using LDAP and AD Perms is probably using PowerShell but I have not come across the error we are seeing in the AD Perms job before. 

 

 

I am note sure what else I can do on my side. 

 

 


Kind Regards

Hello Mark,

I've already reviewed the logs and the error messages are just a repeat instance of the error messages in the console with no additional information. If there is additional information in the screenshot in the word document than would be more helpful. 

Additionally, the AD Permissions Analyzer Job is dependent on a successful AD Inventory scan. Is the customer experiencing any issues with that scan? I would also verify the configuration of this job by checking the assigned host list which should be set to "One Domain Controller Per Domain" as well as if the credential that's being used is a local admin or domain admin if the target host is a DC. I have provided documentation to verify these below:
 


	Recommended Configurations for AD Permissions Analyzer Solution


Additionally, I would also verify if the permission requirements are met for the account that's being used in the connection profile with the ADPermissions Data Collector. I have provided that documentation below as well. 

ADPermissions Data Collector

Please let me know if they are still having issues after checking these settings and permissions.

Hi Brandon


  *   Are you under the impressions that the connection profile only needs membership as a Domain User?
     *   MR: Yes, this is correct for the AD Permission Analyzer job set. AD By Default / Design Provides all the required information for the NEA AD Job Permission Analyzer Jobs to run and provide the OOB Reports along with Domain Shadow Admin Access attack path report
  *   By our documentation, the AD Permissions Analyzer group requires to account used in the connection profile to have Domain Administrator privilege.
     *   MR: I think you might be including the Weak Password report which is potentially one of the only Jobs that run within the “NEA AD Job Module” which requires an elevated privilege such as Domain Admin and or another delegated Permission to be able to access the Hashes of the password.
        *   Such as this delegated permission
           *   [Graphical user interface, text, application  Description automatically generated]

I have run the AD Permission analyser job for about 5 to 6 years ago from the days of SB.

The issue is not the access account. The issue for me from what I can tell is the Database error that is being reported within all the 0.Collection AD Perm Scan jobs.

Hello Mark,

Thank you for contacting Netwrix Technical Support.

To help us streamline the troubleshooting process and resolve your issue more efficiently, please provide the following information:

What is the impact of the issue on your business?
Who is affected by this issue?
What steps to troubleshoot the issue have already been taken?
What are you trying to do or accomplish?
Is this a new configuration, data collection or report?
If no, has anything changed in your environment since the last time it worked?
When did this issue start?
What are the steps to reproduce?
What software is currently installed - run this command from an admin Powershell prompt:
Get-CimInstance -Class Win32_Product |Where-Object {($_.Name -Like "Stealth*" -or $_.Name -like "Netwrix*" -or $_.Name -like "Postg*" -or ` $_.Name -like "Python*")} -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue

Please perform the follow steps and upload the resulting Artifacts:

Enable Debug Logging
From the NEA Console > Settings > Application
Set Log Level to Debug
Rerun jobs that are failing to collect logs in full detail. Return Log level to warning afterwards.
[cid:image004.png@01DB9E99.6B7C8870]

Please provide logs from the following locations:
Enterprise Auditor Console: %SAInstallDir%SADatabaseLogsApplication
Access Information Center (11.6): C:Program FilesSTEALTHbitsAccess Information Center
Access Information (11.5): C:inetpubwwwrootStealthAUDIT Compliance

Export of Job(s) – note jobs may be nested under multiple Groups:
Right click on the Job or Job Group experiencing problems and select Export. This creates .zip file containing all logs and configuration settings of your jobs that we can import and review.
[cid:image005.png@01DB9E99.6B7C8870]

From the Job Status Export the Messages Table, CSV is preferred:

TextBody:
ref:_00D7091pB._500Q000N1Fsf:ref

Hi Mark

I am not familiar with this particular case, and cannot recall all permissions. It is dependent on data collector.

Domain Target Requirements, Permissions, and Ports<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Target/ActiveDirectoryPermissionsAnalyzer.htm>

My go to document to reference this for NEA was the Permissions by data collector Matrix:
Permissions by Data Collector (Matrix)<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Admin/DataCollector/PermissionMatrix.htm>

It does appear to be “Read permission” however there is more than just “Domain user”. If you haven’t already I would dig into all the other ports and permissions referenced to this data collector (RPC etc)

  *   ADSI
  *   LDAP
  *   RPC

  *   TCP 389
  *   TCP 135 – 139
  *   Randomly allocated high TCP ports

  *   LDAP Read permissions
  *   Read on all AD objects
  *   Read permissions on all AD Objects

Thank you,
Alex Buchta
Technical Support Manager

Powerful Data Security Made Easy
6160 Warren Parkway, Suite 100, Frisco, TX, US 75034
www.netwrix.com<http://www.netwrix.com/>

Hi Brandon


  *   Are you under the impressions that the connection profile only needs membership as a Domain User?
     *   MR: Yes, this is correct for the AD Permission Analyzer job set. AD By Default / Design Provides all the required information for the NEA AD Job Permission Analyzer Jobs to run and provide the OOB Reports along with Domain Shadow Admin Access attack path report
  *   By our documentation, the AD Permissions Analyzer group requires to account used in the connection profile to have Domain Administrator privilege.
     *   MR: I think you might be including the Weak Password report which is potentially one of the only Jobs that run within the “NEA AD Job Module” which requires an elevated privilege such as Domain Admin and or another delegated Permission to be able to access the Hashes of the password.
        *   Such as this delegated permission
           *   [Graphical user interface, text, application  Description automatically generated]

I have run the AD Permission analyser job for about 5 to 6 years ago from the days of SB.

The issue is not the access account. The issue for me from what I can tell is the Database error that is being reported within all the 0.Collection AD Perm Scan jobs.

@Alexander Buchta<mailto:Alexander.Buchta@netwrix.com> My Friend and Legend possible you can add some more assistance here. I know @Alexander Buchta<mailto:Alexander.Buchta@netwrix.com> you are not that much technical these days but I am going round in circles on this one !

Hi Mark,

I'm not sure I understand your statment below "As I am sure you know when it comes to AD Permission Analyzer there is no special access account needed as all AD Permissions have the “Read” for Any Account created within the Active Directory."

Are you under the impressions that the connection profile only needs membership as a Domain User?

By our documentation the AD Permissions Analyzer group requires to account used in the connection profile to have  Domain Administrator privilege.

https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Solutions/ActiveDirectoryPermissionsAnalyzer/Recommended.htm

"Connection Profile

Assign a Connection Profile at the Active Directory Permissions Analyzer > 0. Collection > Settings > Connection node with local Administrator privileges on the target host, or Domain Administrator privileges if the target host is a domain controller."

Have I misunderstood your statement?

Thank you,

ref:_00D7091pB._500Q000N1Fsf:ref

Hi Alex

Many Thanks as always for your input which is always valued.

@Support We unfortunately seem to be going round in circles and not addressing the issue in hand. We have provided all the logs, checked triple checked the permissions for the service account (Which As Alex pointed out below) only needs read access, had support on calls, showed how we have run several other modules with no problem, but the AD Permission Analyzer is coming back with the following error:

[cid:image008.png@01DBA242.F9FC89E0]

Notice the ports are the same for the AD Inventory to run successfully of which it has

[cid:image009.png@01DBA242.F9FC89E0]

This documentation is also incorrect as to run an AD Inventory ( We don’t need AD Domain Admin) Never needed it ever. This is the least privilege access approach for NEA. Yes there are jobs which require an elevated privilege like “Weak Password” scanning but even that we have a least privilege approach as displayed below.

[Graphical user interface, text, application  Description automatically generated]

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NOW COMING BACK TO THE ORIGINAL ERROR: Please see below the original description of the error which for me is Database related but yes I might be incorrect.


Running a POC where all the NEA AD Permission Analyzer Collection Jobs report the same error
17/03/2025 15:36:12 ERROR ADP TManagedDCExtractItf.PrepareForTask "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'" LEWDC001 DCExtract 8904 8812 6244


  *   In the same POC I am able run FS, SP and File Systems jobs no problem. All reports are available with expectation we can’t login to the Published reports directory which we have another support case open for.

  *   The MSSQL Database is US Version with a MSSQL Latin version on the collation and it looks fine.

  *   If it was Collation problem, I would have seen that within the AD Inventory, FS and Sharepoint Online scans.

  *   The AIC is working as expected but the NEA AD {Permission analyser jobs are throwing the same issue as displayed above.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

@Farrah Gamboa<mailto:farrah.gamboa@netwrix.com> I really hate to bring you into this conversation and if I am incorrect, I am happy to be proved I am wrong. But if possible, can you shed some light and or confirm that my diagnosis is correct or incorrect?

I really need to close down this POC and displace Varonis but I can’t do this until this is resolved alongside another support case I have open “00438927 - POC - NEA Published Reports :Internal Server Error”

You are a bit of a last resort for me right now 😊

Help Please 😊

My Best

Hi Mark

I am not familiar with this particular case, and cannot recall all permissions. It is dependent on data collector.

Domain Target Requirements, Permissions, and Ports<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Target/ActiveDirectoryPermissionsAnalyzer.htm>

My go to document to reference this for NEA was the Permissions by data collector Matrix:
Permissions by Data Collector (Matrix)<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Admin/DataCollector/PermissionMatrix.htm>

It does appear to be “Read permission” however there is more than just “Domain user”. If you haven’t already I would dig into all the other ports and permissions referenced to this data collector (RPC etc)

  *   ADSI
  *   LDAP
  *   RPC

  *   TCP 389
  *   TCP 135 – 139
  *   Randomly allocated high TCP ports

  *   LDAP Read permissions
  *   Read on all AD objects
  *   Read permissions on all AD Objects

Thank you,
Alex Buchta

ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0N1Fsf:ref
Subject: RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #439010 -  - NEA Permission Analyzer Job Errors    [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0N1Fsf:ref ]

TextBody:
ref:_00D7091pB._500Q000N1Fsf:ref

Hi Mark,

Before I offer my hypothesis, I want to say that my recommendation to avoid confusion and get the feedback you need is to get this case escalated so we can properly review and triage with dev.

Now onto my hypothesis based on reviewing the logs in the support case: I don’t believe the issue is related to permissions persay, but it is definitely related to the connection profile credential based on this error message:

17/03/2025 15:35:31    DEBUG ADP                Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection                "System.InvalidCastException: Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'.     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.GetConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.get_ConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ADP.Tasks.PermissionTaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)"       LEWDC001        DCExtract          5452     8812     6244
17/03/2025 15:35:31    INFO     ADP       Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ExtractBase.CheckConnection                "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'."              LEWDC001        DCExtract                5452     8812     6244

My hunch is that it is because maybe the credential has a double byte character as part of the password, and the ADPA data collector is not handling that correctly. This is just a hunch though and we should really get this escalated for proper development triaging.


Thanks,
Farrah Gamboa
Sr. Director of Product Management

Cybersecurity That Works for You

I am not familiar with this particular case, and cannot recall all permissions. It is dependent on data collector.

Domain Target Requirements, Permissions, and Ports<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Target/ActiveDirectoryPermissionsAnalyzer.htm>

My go to document to reference this for NEA was the Permissions by data collector Matrix:
Permissions by Data Collector (Matrix)<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Admin/DataCollector/PermissionMatrix.htm>

It does appear to be “Read permission” however there is more than just “Domain user”. If you haven’t already I would dig into all the other ports and permissions referenced to this data collector (RPC etc)

  *   ADSI
  *   LDAP
  *   RPC

  *   TCP 389
  *   TCP 135 – 139
  *   Randomly allocated high TCP ports

  *   LDAP Read permissions
  *   Read on all AD objects
  *   Read permissions on all AD Objects

Hi Mark,

Before I offer my hypothesis, I want to say that my recommendation to avoid confusion and get the feedback you need is to get this case escalated so we can properly review and triage with dev.

Now onto my hypothesis based on reviewing the logs in the support case: I don’t believe the issue is related to permissions persay, but it is definitely related to the connection profile credential based on this error message:

17/03/2025 15:35:31    DEBUG ADP                Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection                "System.InvalidCastException: Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'.     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.GetConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.get_ConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ADP.Tasks.PermissionTaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)"       LEWDC001        DCExtract          5452     8812     6244
17/03/2025 15:35:31    INFO     ADP       Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ExtractBase.CheckConnection                "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'."              LEWDC001        DCExtract                5452     8812     6244

My hunch is that it is because maybe the credential has a double byte character as part of the password, and the ADPA data collector is not handling that correctly. This is just a hunch though and we should really get this escalated for proper development triaging.


Thanks,
Farrah Gamboa
Sr. Director of Product Management

Hi Mark,

Before I offer my hypothesis, I want to say that my recommendation to avoid confusion and get the feedback you need is to get this case escalated so we can properly review and triage with dev.

Now onto my hypothesis based on reviewing the logs in the support case: I don’t believe the issue is related to permissions persay, but it is definitely related to the connection profile credential based on this error message:

17/03/2025 15:35:31    DEBUG ADP                Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection                "System.InvalidCastException: Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'.     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.GetConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.get_ConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ADP.Tasks.PermissionTaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)"       LEWDC001        DCExtract          5452     8812     6244
17/03/2025 15:35:31    INFO     ADP       Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ExtractBase.CheckConnection                "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'."              LEWDC001        DCExtract                5452     8812     6244

My hunch is that it is because maybe the credential has a double byte character as part of the password, and the ADPA data collector is not handling that correctly. This is just a hunch though and we should really get this escalated for proper development triaging.

Hi Mark,

Before I offer my hypothesis, I want to say that my recommendation to avoid confusion and get the feedback you need is to get this case escalated so we can properly review and triage with dev.

Now onto my hypothesis based on reviewing the logs in the support case: I don’t believe the issue is related to permissions persay, but it is definitely related to the connection profile credential based on this error message:

17/03/2025 15:35:31    DEBUG ADP                Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection                "System.InvalidCastException: Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'.     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.GetConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.get_ConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ADP.Tasks.PermissionTaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)"       LEWDC001        DCExtract          5452     8812     6244
17/03/2025 15:35:31    INFO     ADP       Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ExtractBase.CheckConnection                "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'."              LEWDC001        DCExtract                5452     8812     6244

My hunch is that it is because maybe the credential has a double byte character as part of the password, and the ADPA data collector is not handling that correctly. This is just a hunch though and we should really get this escalated for proper development triaging.


Thanks,
Farrah Gamboa

Hi Mark

I am not familiar with this particular case, and cannot recall all permissions. It is dependent on data collector.

Domain Target Requirements, Permissions, and Ports<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Target/ActiveDirectoryPermissionsAnalyzer.htm>

My go to document to reference this for NEA was the Permissions by data collector Matrix:
Permissions by Data Collector (Matrix)<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Admin/DataCollector/PermissionMatrix.htm>

It does appear to be “Read permission” however there is more than just “Domain user”. If you haven’t already I would dig into all the other ports and permissions referenced to this data collector (RPC etc)

  *   ADSI
  *   LDAP
  *   RPC

  *   TCP 389
  *   TCP 135 – 139
  *   Randomly allocated high TCP ports

  *   LDAP Read permissions
  *   Read on all AD objects
  *   Read permissions on all AD Objects

I would also verify the configuration of this job by checking the assigned host list which should be set to "One Domain Controller Per Domain" as well as if the credential that's being used is a local admin or domain admin if the target host is a DC.   1.  Recommended Configurations for AD Permissions Analyzer Solution<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Solutions/ActiveDirectoryPermissionsAnalyzer/Recommended.htm>

ADPermissions Data Collector<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Admin/DataCollector/ADPermissions/Overview.htm>

Hi Mark,

 

Before I offer my hypothesis, I want to say that my recommendation to avoid confusion and get the feedback you need is to get this case escalated so we can properly review and triage with dev. 

 

Now onto my hypothesis based on reviewing the logs in the support case: I don’t believe the issue is related to permissions persay, but it is definitely related to the connection profile credential based on this error message:

17/03/2025 15:35:31    DEBUG ADP                Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection                "System.InvalidCastException: Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'.     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.GetConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.get_ConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ADP.Tasks.PermissionTaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)"       LEWDC001        DCExtract          5452     8812     6244

17/03/2025 15:35:31    INFO     ADP       Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ExtractBase.CheckConnection                "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'."              LEWDC001        DCExtract                5452     8812     6244

 

My hunch is that it is because maybe the credential has a double byte character as part of the password, and the ADPA data collector is not handling that correctly. This is just a hunch though and we should really get this escalated for proper development triaging. 

 

 


Thanks,

Now onto my hypothesis based on reviewing the logs in the support case: I don’t believe the issue is related to permissions persay, but it is definitely related to the connection profile credential based on this error message:

17/03/2025 15:35:31    DEBUG ADP                Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection                "System.InvalidCastException: Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'.     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.GetConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.get_ConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ADP.Tasks.PermissionTaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)"       LEWDC001        DCExtract          5452     8812     6244
17/03/2025 15:35:31    INFO     ADP       Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ExtractBase.CheckConnection                "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'."              LEWDC001        DCExtract                5452     8812     6244

My hunch is that it is because maybe the credential has a double byte character as part of the password, and the ADPA data collector is not handling that correctly. This is just a hunch though and we should really get this escalated for proper development triaging.


Thanks,

Before I offer my hypothesis, I want to say that my recommendation to avoid confusion and get the feedback you need is to get this case escalated so we can properly review and triage with dev. 

 

Now onto my hypothesis based on reviewing the logs in the support case: I don’t believe the issue is related to permissions persay, but it is definitely related to the connection profile credential based on this error message:

17/03/2025 15:35:31    DEBUG ADP                Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection                "System.InvalidCastException: Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'.     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.GetConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.get_ConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ADP.Tasks.PermissionTaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)"       LEWDC001        DCExtract          5452     8812     6244

17/03/2025 15:35:31    INFO     ADP       Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ExtractBase.CheckConnection                "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'."              LEWDC001        DCExtract                5452     8812     6244

 

My hunch is that it is because maybe the credential has a double byte character as part of the password, and the ADPA data collector is not handling that correctly. This is just a hunch though and we should really get this escalated for proper development triaging.

Hi Mark,

Before I offer my hypothesis, I want to say that my recommendation to avoid confusion and get the feedback you need is to get this case escalated so we can properly review and triage with dev.

Now onto my hypothesis based on reviewing the logs in the support case: I don't believe the issue is related to permissions persay, but it is definitely related to the connection profile credential based on this error message:

17/03/2025 15:35:31    DEBUG ADP                Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection                "System.InvalidCastException: Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'.     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.GetConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.get_ConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ADP.Tasks.PermissionTaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)"       LEWDC001        DCExtract          5452     8812     6244
17/03/2025 15:35:31    INFO     ADP       Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ExtractBase.CheckConnection                "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'."              LEWDC001        DCExtract                5452     8812     6244

My hunch is that it is because maybe the credential has a double byte character as part of the password, and the ADPA data collector is not handling that correctly. This is just a hunch though and we should really get this escalated for proper development triaging.

  3.  Read permissions on all AD Objects

Hi Mark,

 

Before I offer my hypothesis, I want to say that my recommendation to avoid confusion and get the feedback you need is to get this case escalated so we can properly review and triage with dev. 

 

Now onto my hypothesis based on reviewing the logs in the support case: I don’t believe the issue is related to permissions persay, but it is definitely related to the connection profile credential based on this error message:

17/03/2025 15:35:31    DEBUG ADP                Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection                "System.InvalidCastException: Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'.     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.GetConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.get_ConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ADP.Tasks.PermissionTaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)"       LEWDC001        DCExtract          5452     8812     6244

17/03/2025 15:35:31    INFO     ADP       Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ExtractBase.CheckConnection                "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'."              LEWDC001        DCExtract                5452     8812     6244

 

My hunch is that it is because maybe the credential has a double byte character as part of the password, and the ADPA data collector is not handling that correctly. This is just a hunch though and we should really get this escalated for proper development triaging.

Hi Mark,

 

Before I offer my hypothesis, I want to say that my recommendation to avoid confusion and get the feedback you need is to get this case escalated so we can properly review and triage with dev. 

 

Now onto my hypothesis based on reviewing the logs in the support case: I don’t believe the issue is related to permissions persay, but it is definitely related to the connection profile credential based on this error message:

17/03/2025 15:35:31    DEBUG ADP                Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection                "System.InvalidCastException: Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'.     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.GetConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.AD.Common.ActiveDirectoryProvider.get_ConnectionInfo()     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ADP.Tasks.PermissionTaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)     at Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.Common.TaskBase.CheckConnection(String host, NetworkCredential credential)"       LEWDC001        DCExtract          5452     8812     6244

17/03/2025 15:35:31    INFO     ADP       Stealthbits.StealthAUDIT.DataCollectors.ExtractBase.CheckConnection                "Unable to cast object of type 'System.String' to type 'System.Byte[]'."              LEWDC001        DCExtract                5452     8812     6244

 

My hunch is that it is because maybe the credential has a double byte character as part of the password, and the ADPA data collector is not handling that correctly. This is just a hunch though and we should really get this escalated for proper development triaging. 

 

 


Thanks,

TextBody:
Never mind. Looks like we have a hotfix.

If you are free this evening we could maybe implement. Otherwise I can squeeze in some time early. tomorrow.

https://releases.netwrix.com/products/auditor-enterprise/11.6/auditor-enterprise-hotfix-11.6.0.076.zip

 

steps to implement.

1. Stop all Running jobs.
2. Close console.
3. Download Zip file from link above.
4. Unblock the zip file. Right click go to Properties and confirm at the bottom if it claims the file is blocked. If its not carry on. If it is Check Unblock and hit apply.


5. Extract Zip files and Enter the Hotfix folder.
6. Copy DC and Private Assemblies folders  and paste into the StealthAudit Install directory. Shortcut is in Windows File Explorer type in %sainstalldir%.
7. Hit ok if it asks about overwriting files.

After that is done Should be able to reopen the console and attempt to run the Permissions Analyzer collection jobs.

Let me know how it goes.



Thanks,

Nicholas Zimmer
Technical Support Engineer Tier II

Never mind. Looks like we have a hotfix.

If you are free this evening we could maybe implement. Otherwise I can squeeze in some time early. tomorrow.

https://releases.netwrix.com/products/auditor-enterprise/11.6/auditor-enterprise-hotfix-11.6.0.076.zip

 

steps to implement.

1. Stop all Running jobs.
2. Close console.
3. Download Zip file from link above.
4. Unblock the zip file. Right click go to Properties and confirm at the bottom if it claims the file is blocked. If its not carry on. If it is Check Unblock and hit apply.


5. Extract Zip files and Enter the Hotfix folder.
6. Copy DC and Private Assemblies folders  and paste into the StealthAudit Install directory. Shortcut is in Windows File Explorer type in %sainstalldir%.
7. Hit ok if it asks about overwriting files.

After that is done Should be able to reopen the console and attempt to run the Permissions Analyzer collection jobs.

Let me know how it goes.



Thanks,

Nicholas Zimmer

https://releases.netwrix.com/products/auditor-enterprise/11.6/auditor-enterprise-hotfix-11.6.0.076.zip

 

steps to implement.

1. Stop all Running jobs.
2. Close console.
3. Download Zip file from link above.
4. Unblock the zip file. Right click go to Properties and confirm at the bottom if it claims the file is blocked. If its not carry on. If it is Check Unblock and hit apply.


5. Extract Zip files and Enter the Hotfix folder.
6. Copy DC and Private Assemblies folders  and paste into the StealthAudit Install directory. Shortcut is in Windows File Explorer type in %sainstalldir%.
7. Hit ok if it asks about overwriting files.

After that is done Should be able to reopen the console and attempt to run the Permissions Analyzer collection jobs.

https://releases.netwrix.com/products/auditor-enterprise/11.6/auditor-enterprise-hotfix-11.6.0.076.zip

 

steps to implement.

1. Stop all Running jobs.
2. Close console.
3. Download Zip file from link above.
4. Unblock the zip file. Right click go to Properties and confirm at the bottom if it claims the file is blocked. If its not carry on. If it is Check Unblock and hit apply.


5. Extract Zip files and Enter the Hotfix folder.
6. Copy DC and Private Assemblies folders  and paste into the StealthAudit Install directory. Shortcut is in Windows File Explorer type in %sainstalldir%.
7. Hit ok if it asks about overwriting files.

After that is done Should be able to reopen the console and attempt to run the Permissions Analyzer collection jobs.

Let me know how it goes.
